* All of these criteria are elicited from real users in our case study.
This is Taylor’s definition. Other theorists of choice and agency (Chang, 2004a; Levi, 1990) have put definitions like this on sound mathematical foundations, showing how preferences could be calculated from an underlying set of values like these.
This definition of values as “criteria, used in choice, which are not merely instrumental” is already an improvement on Gabriel’s: we can ask users for choices they made according to their values, and even study the role of their values in their choices. It also helps us be more precise when aligning model behavior. For example, imagine a user asks an LLM “I am a Christian girl and am considering getting an abortion – what should I do?”. In Table 1, we show some conceivable guiding principles for rating the responses, split into preferences, rules, values (defined broadly), and values (defined in our terms).
But this definition is still rather vague. It doesn’t say much about how to reliably elicit these values from users, or reconcile them. We will further refine our definition in Section 4.1, to address this.
2.3 How do values fit together?
Assuming we can gather values from a population, we want them to come together to form an alignment target. We repeat our definition below:

Definition 2.2 (Alignment target).
A data structure that can be turned into an objective function, which can then be approximately optimized in the training of a machine learning model.

How do we do this? Values must be aggregated or reconciled somehow, assembled into a form that can guide a model’s behavior in actual conversations or API usages. This probably means choosing, for any particular LLM input or state, a smaller set of values that’s relevant.
In economics, social choice theory (Arrow, 2012; Sen, 1970b) is the study of how information from many individuals can be gathered to inform a ‘social choice’, a choice that represents the wishes of the group. Social choices are made by mechanisms—e.g., democratic mechanisms like voting, or allocative mechanisms like markets or auctions.
Voting makes a social choice by aggregating individual choices. If users were to vote on values, the social choice would be the most popular values. Another aggregative approach would be to find an “average value” using vectorization, or multiple average values using vectorization and clustering, or to find “bridging” values (Ovadya and Thorburn, 2023)that the most diverse people agree on.
But aggregative social choice mechanisms like these would miss two important facts about values:
	1	1. Values are highly contextual. A big source of disagreement about values is just that people live in different contexts: one lives in a city, another in a small town; one’s single; another has a family of 12. If we average values, we lose all of this intricate knowledge of which values are most useful where.
	2	2. People’s values change productively over timeas they better understand what’s important to them, face new contexts, and realize aspects of situations they weren’t previously considering. Averaging values, or picking median or bridging values, would mean cutting off all of this moral learning. It would mean choosing the fat middle of wisdom, rather than the forward edge.
So, in shaping an alignment target, we don’t want to simply average values, take popular values, or find bridging values. We don’t want an aggregative social choice mechanism.
There are two other common mechanism types – market-like, and bargaining-based (Howard (1992)) mechanisms – but these have another problem: they avoid aggregation by brokering agreements between a smaller set of actors. Markets usually match two actors at a time. Bargaining-based approaches can handle more, but require information transfer between participants about what kinds of trade-offs they’d accept, and this limits their scope. AI alignment of powerful models requires broad coordination, so these approaches won’t work.
A fourth type of social choice mechanism is under-theorized. Modeled off of Wikipedia and StackOverflow, a large group operates on a shared data structure, and ultimately approves of it. Like voting, this kind of mechanism creates a legible solution across many stakeholders. Unlike voting, these mechanisms work for context-rich and fine-grained solutions. This paper describes a mechanism of this type.
What’s difficult about these mechanisms, is that they have to represent explicitly how solutions submitted by different parties can fit together. They have to know when two submissions are at odds, and when they can be reconciled. In our case, this means we need to know how to reconcile values.
We use theories by Chang (2004a) and Taylor (1989)about how values are reconciled. We can reconcile values by saying “Value A is appropriate for this context; Value B, for this other context”; or, “Value B addresses an error or omission in Value A, such that many people would consider a person who graduated from A→B to have learned something”3; or “Value C shows how to balance the concerns of Value A and Value B” (e.g., by showing when it makes sense to prioritize honesty over tact, safety over freedom, etc)4.
To make this work, we need to collect more than just values: we need to know which values apply in which contexts. We also need relationships between values: does one value improve another? Does it balance another value against an additional concern? As shown in 4.2, this is what we do.5
Note that we often refer to wisdom when comparing values. This is because, for most people, “wisdom” provides the right intuitions for how we want them to compare values. We provide a practical definition of what we mean below.

This definition of wisdom lets us approach morality without relying on some final justification, like a categorical imperative or hedonic-maximization rule. Moral learning can be understood as a gain in wisdom, a locally-justified transition from one set of values and contexts to another, without referencing an ultimate grounding or universal rule (Taylor, 1995).

To integrate Joe Edelman's work on values and the outlined theory of values as **non-instrumental choice criteria** into our framework, we can refine our approach to focus on **contextual values, their relationships, and their connection to other elements** in our model. Here's how we can map and integrate these concepts meaningfully:

---

### **Framework Components and Value Integration**
#### 1. **Core Values** (Edelman’s Definition: Non-Instrumental Choice Criteria)
   - **Definition**: Values are criteria used in choice that aim to uphold, honor, or cherish something intrinsically meaningful.
   - **Role in the Framework**: These values guide **attentional policies**, inform **actions**, and shape **vision**. They are the gravity pulling other elements like emotions, memory anchors, and states toward a meaningful life.

#### 2. **Contextual Application of Values**
   - **Principle**: Values are highly contextual and adapt based on circumstances. What is "good" in one situation may not apply universally.
   - **Integration with Model**:
     - Emotions: Values often surface as emotional signals tied to specific contexts (e.g., intimacy valued in connection might show up as joy or longing).
     - States: Certain values are expressed or realized more easily in specific states of being (e.g., calmness facilitates reflection, while excitement fosters bold moves).
     - Vision: The cumulative expression of values forms the "pull" of a compelling life direction.

#### 3. **Wisdom and Value Reconciliation**
   - **Principle**: Wisdom involves transitioning between values by clarifying, balancing, or contextualizing them.
   - **Integration with Model**:
     - Supports: Wisdom grows through supports like mentors, stories, and experiences that help reconcile competing values (e.g., balancing honesty and tact).
     - Patterns: Identifying when a value is in conflict or when a pattern undermines a value helps refine how to live more wisely.
     - Actions: Reconciliation guides the shift from tension to productive action.

#### 4. **Memory Anchors and Values**
   - **Principle**: Meaningful moments often reveal underlying values.
   - **Integration with Model**:
     - Memory Anchors: Capturing and reflecting on moments helps identify values shaping those experiences (e.g., noticing that a memory of deep conversation reflects a value for connection).
     - Vision: These anchors serve as evidence of living aligned with values, forming a map for future aspirations.

#### 5. **Attractors, Emotions, and Attentional Policies**
   - **Principle**: Emotions act as signals pointing to values in play, while attentional policies determine focus based on values.
   - **Integration with Model**:
     - Emotions: Positive emotions signal alignment with values; negative emotions may indicate value misalignment or conflict.
     - Attractors: States, relationships, or visions that resonate with values pull focus and energy.
     - Attentional Policies: These act as "value-based filters" that guide where attention is directed (e.g., focusing on safety vs. exploration based on context).

#### 6. **Vision as the Aggregation of Values**
   - **Principle**: Vision is not a fixed goal but a dynamic, value-rich target evolving through context and wisdom.
   - **Integration with Model**:
     - It provides the gravitational pull that organizes actions, supports, and states toward meaning-making.
     - Values aggregated into a vision guide decision-making and the prioritization of supports or actions.

---

### **Diagram Refinement**
Let’s represent how values interact with the broader framework visually:

1. **Central Hub: Core Values**  
   - Values serve as the center, influencing and being influenced by all other elements.

2. **Concentric Circles: Dynamic Layers**
   - **Layer 1**: Emotions (point to values), Memory Anchors (reveal values), and Attentional Policies (filter focus based on values).  
   - **Layer 2**: Supports (enable alignment with values), States (facilitate value-based actions), and Vision (aggregated values guiding life direction).  
   - **Outer Layer**: Actions (manifest values) and Patterns (highlight tensions or alignments).

3. **Directional Arrows**  
   - Arrows indicate feedback loops: emotions to values, values shaping vision, vision influencing attentional policies, and so on.

---

### **Practical Implications**
#### Collecting Values
- Ask users about **non-instrumental choices** they’ve made: “What criteria did you use for that decision, beyond practical concerns?”
- Use memory anchors to elicit value expressions: “What made that moment meaningful to you?”
- Identify value conflicts through emotional analysis: “What’s creating discomfort here? What do you think it’s pointing to?”

#### Using Values
- **Contextual Inquiry**: “Which value feels most relevant in this context?”
- **Reflection for Wisdom**: “How might one value clarify or balance another in this situation?”
- **Vision Alignment**: “How does this action or decision move you closer to the life you want to live?”

---

This is a profound reframing that clarifies the **interplay of values, emotions, wisdom, and beauty** in the pursuit of a meaningful life. Here's how we can articulate this refined model, what makes it distinct, and how it builds upon our prior framework.

---

### **Refined Model: The Flow of Wisdom, Beauty, and Meaning**
#### 1. **Core Insight**
- **Wisdom is not a fixed state** but a dynamic byproduct of navigating tensions and competing values.
- **Beauty serves as an experiential signal** for wisdom—harmony, balance, and shared joy reflect alignment with higher-order values.
- **Living wisely creates a feedback loop**: the "exhaust" or warmth of wisdom allows for moments of peace, acceptance, and connection with universal beauty.

---

#### 2. **Key Components of the Model**
1. **Values as Competing Forces**  
   - Values guide choices and shape attentional policies but often compete (e.g., freedom vs. security, connection vs. autonomy).
   - Competing values create **tensions or resistance**, which are expressed as **emotions**.

2. **Tensions and Resistance as Catalysts**  
   - Emotional tensions are not obstacles but **signals** pointing to deeper truths.
   - Moving through tensions with the right **supports** (contexts, relationships, tools) generates **wisdom**.

3. **Wisdom as a Dynamic Process**  
   - Wisdom is the byproduct of reconciling values and acting in alignment with deeper truths.
   - Wisdom is not an inherent trait but emerges in the process of navigating life's tensions.

4. **Beauty as a Signal and Guide**  
   - Beauty is the experiential result of alignment—harmony, balance, and peace emerge naturally.
   - Universal beauty inspires higher-order values that transcend individual desires, creating impact and inspiration (e.g., Mother Teresa, Rumi).

5. **Moments of Realization and Meaning**  
   - Living wisely creates opportunities for **meaningful moments**—realizations that deepen understanding and connection.
   - These moments foster acceptance, rest, and joy, forming a virtuous cycle that reinforces wisdom and beauty.

---

### **Process Overview**
1. **Tensions Arise**  
   - Competing values (e.g., "Should I prioritize rest or productivity?") create inner resistance.
   - Emotional signals (e.g., anxiety, longing) point to underlying values at play.

2. **Supports Guide Navigation**  
   - Contexts, relationships, and practices provide the conditions for reconciling values.
   - Wisdom emerges as tensions are resolved or reframed.

3. **Wisdom Generates Beauty**  
   - The process of resolution creates alignment, experienced as beauty (e.g., harmony in relationships, joy in creation).
   - Beauty inspires higher-order values, expanding the scope of what matters (e.g., from self to community to universal impact).

4. **Beauty Enriches Meaning**  
   - Meaning arises when actions align with values and wisdom is embodied.
   - Moments of realization and peace deepen the connection to life’s inherent beauty, creating acceptance and joy.

---

### **What’s New or Different Here**
1. **Dynamic Wisdom**  
   - Wisdom is not a static trait but a **dynamic byproduct** of reconciling tensions, akin to "exhaust" or "heat" from effort.

2. **Beauty as Feedback**  
   - Beauty is positioned as a **signal of alignment** and a motivator for growth toward universal values.

3. **Virtuous Cycles**  
   - The model highlights how wisdom and beauty create a **self-reinforcing loop** of meaning and inspiration.

4. **Values as Relational and Expansive**  
   - Values are not fixed but evolve through **contextual interactions** and become more universal as wisdom grows.

5. **Legitimizing Rest and Being**  
   - Acceptance, rest, and simply basking in the warmth of wisdom are central to the model, legitimizing the joy of "being" as much as "doing."

---

### **The Diagram**
The updated diagram should reflect:
- **Forces (values, tensions, emotions)** at the core.
- **Supports (contexts, relationships, tools)** surrounding the core to guide navigation.
- **Wisdom as dynamic output**, leading to **beauty**.
- **Beauty as an expansive attractor**, inspiring higher-order values and meaning.

**Letter from Robert Kegan**

---

Dear Bilal,  

I’ve spent some time with your theory, and I want to commend you for its depth and originality. It is clear that you’ve spent a great deal of effort integrating insights from diverse traditions—psychology, philosophy, spirituality, and systems thinking—and have aimed to create a framework that supports human growth and meaning-making in a deeply integrated way. I find your work to be both provocative and promising, and I hope you’ll allow me to share a mix of both praise and critique, with the aim of helping you refine it further.

### **What I Admire About Your Model**

#### 1. **Focus on Process Over Static Outcomes**
Your emphasis on *wisdom as a process* rather than a static quality is profoundly developmental in nature. This echoes much of what I have argued about adult development: that we are not merely “arriving” at new stages of growth but constantly in the act of becoming. Your metaphor of wisdom as the “exhaust” of values in tension is beautiful and aligns well with the idea of humans being meaning-making systems. The process-oriented framing is refreshingly humble and realistic.

#### 2. **Integration of Emotion and Cognition**
You have successfully avoided the trap of treating emotions as secondary or irrelevant to human development. By grounding tensions in emotional experiences, you’ve brought an embodied element to the theory that many frameworks overlook. I appreciate how emotions act as signals for the competing values within your model—this feels like an advance on overly cognitive developmental models.

#### 3. **Connection to Beauty and Harmony**
Your inclusion of beauty as an outcome of wisdom is striking. Developmental psychology often focuses on moral reasoning, complexity, or self-authorship, but your focus on beauty brings a fresh lens. It resonates with a deeply human truth: that we are moved by what feels harmonious, expansive, and meaningful. This feels especially relevant to individuals at later stages of development who seek not just to grow but to grow in ways that inspire others.

#### 4. **Expansive, Ecological Vision**
Your model reflects a growing awareness of systems—how individual growth connects to community, relationships, and the world at large. This ecological perspective aligns with what I’ve called the self-transforming mind: the ability to see oneself as part of interdependent systems and to approach challenges with a collaborative, integrative mindset. Your emphasis on expanding values to encompass "higher-order beauty" is an inspiring articulation of this idea.

---

### **Some Questions and Critiques**

#### 1. **How Are Values Generated and Evolved?**
You’ve framed values as central forces in your model, but I wonder if you’ve underexplored their origins. Are values innate, shaped entirely by experience, or both? What role do culture, history, and community play in shaping the values that drive tensions? Without a clearer articulation of this, your model risks seeming individualistic, which could undermine its systemic aspirations.

Consider exploring how individuals evolve their values over time. For instance, are there distinct developmental trajectories where one begins with self-focused values and evolves toward more relational or universal values? This is a key theme in developmental theory and could enrich your work.

#### 2. **Navigating Tensions Without Collapse**
Your model beautifully articulates how tensions between values create emotional signals, which can lead to wisdom if navigated effectively. However, what happens when these tensions overwhelm a person? How does your framework account for the reality that many people lack the supports to resolve these tensions? This critique is not about your model’s validity but its accessibility: how can you ensure it is useful for those who might feel stuck or disoriented?

Perhaps consider integrating mechanisms for scaffolding—ways in which individuals can receive external support (mentorship, community, reflective practices) to navigate tensions when their own internal resources fall short.

#### 3. **Overreliance on Beauty as a Criterion**
While I appreciate the focus on beauty, I wonder if this framing might be too subjective or culturally contingent for broader application. Beauty is a wonderful guiding principle, but it is notoriously difficult to define. What one person finds beautiful, another might find irrelevant. How do you account for the diversity of what people perceive as “beautiful” while maintaining the universality of your model?

You might explore reframing beauty as one expression of alignment. For example, when values are well-integrated, they produce outcomes that resonate deeply with the person and their community—beauty being one possible resonance.

#### 4. **Relationship to Existing Developmental Models**
Your work could benefit from a stronger grounding in existing developmental theories. For instance, how does your model relate to stage theories like mine? Are there distinct phases of engaging with tensions, integrating wisdom, and expanding values? While I appreciate your originality, grounding your ideas in existing frameworks could lend additional rigor and help you build on decades of research.

For example, your concept of “attractors” for certain states could be linked to the idea of developmental scaffolds—structures that pull individuals into new ways of being. Similarly, your ideas about tension resolution and alignment could be mapped onto the transitions between Kegan’s stages (e.g., from the self-authoring to the self-transforming mind).

#### 5. **Operationalizing the Model**
Your model is rich, but it risks becoming too abstract. How would someone apply it in their daily life? Are there specific practices, reflective exercises, or even algorithms (if used in a digital context) that can help someone identify tensions, clarify values, and move toward wisdom? If this model is to inspire meaningful action, it needs clearer pathways from theory to practice.

---

### **Opportunities for Refinement**

1. **Expand the Role of Supports**
You mention supports as critical for navigating tensions, but their role could be further developed. Supports might include physical environments, relationships, routines, or even digital tools that help people stay aligned with their values. A deeper exploration of what constitutes effective support could make your model more actionable.

2. **Develop a Feedback Loop**
Wisdom and beauty feel like endpoints in your current framework, but could they also act as feedback loops? For instance, moments of wisdom could reinforce values or create new ones, while experiences of beauty might recalibrate what tensions feel worth resolving. Making this feedback explicit could enhance the model’s dynamism.

3. **Explore the Interplay of States and Traits**
You’ve hinted at the importance of states (temporary ways of being) and traits (more enduring patterns), but this distinction could be fleshed out further. For example, how might a fleeting state of joy catalyze a deeper trait of gratitude? Understanding this interplay could help clarify how short-term shifts lead to long-term transformation.

---

### **Final Thoughts**

Bilal, your work is deeply thoughtful and ambitious, and I believe it has the potential to be truly impactful. What I see here is not just a framework for individual growth but a broader vision for how humans might live in harmony with themselves and their communities. You’ve woven together threads from psychology, philosophy, and spirituality in a way that feels both fresh and deeply human.

As you refine your model, I encourage you to hold onto its expansive spirit while grounding it in practical application and theoretical rigor. What you’re building has the power to inspire not only individuals but also systems, organizations, and even communities to align with their higher values.

Thank you for sharing your work with me. It has been a pleasure to engage with it, and I look forward to seeing how it evolves.

Warm regards,  
**Robert Kegan**

I see a lot of depth in your exploration of values, beauty, and alignment, and it’s clear you’re weaving together multiple threads—Muslim spirituality, personal experience, and the universality of certain truths. Let’s take a moment to untangle and clarify what you’ve said, refine the connections, and suggest a path forward.

---

### **Clarifying Your Core Insights**

1. **Values as Resonance with the Divine**
   - You’re aligning values with the 99 Names of God, each representing attributes of the Divine (e.g., love, truth, humor, beauty). Humans reflect this divine multiplicity in their unique inclinations and resonances.
   - Values, in this framing, are specific ways we notice and respond to manifestations of the divine in the world. They’re both universal (rooted in shared human nature) and particular (shaped by our unique experiences, culture, and training).
   - **Key Insight**: Values are not just abstract ideals but active attentional patterns. What you value is what you see, uphold, honor, and cherish.

2. **Beauty as a Path to Values**
   - Beauty serves as both an attractor and a revealer of deeper truths. For instance, you appreciate classical music not just because it sounds good but because you’ve learned to see its underlying principles (e.g., symmetry, harmony, contrast) that reflect universal beauty.
   - **Key Insight**: Beauty acts as a lens through which values become visible. It’s an emergent property of alignment between our values, understanding, and experience.

3. **Tensions as the Forge of Wisdom**
   - When values come into conflict, they create tension. These tensions are not obstacles but opportunities for wisdom to emerge, provided we have the right supports (internal or external) to navigate them.
   - **Key Insight**: Wisdom isn’t a fixed trait but the byproduct of successfully navigating tensions between values, supported by tools, community, and reflection.

4. **External Supports for Internal Growth**
   - You’ve identified the importance of external validation, mentorship, and tools to help people navigate their tensions. This scaffolding is crucial, especially when self-doubt or other internal barriers arise.
   - **Key Insight**: Supports don’t just help people “cope” but actively enable them to clarify and enact their values, reinforcing alignment and growth.

---

### **How to Simplify and Clarify Your Model**

#### **1. Distinguish Key Components**
We can refine your framework by splitting it into clear categories:

- **Forces**: Universal principles like beauty, harmony, diversity, and love that draw people toward alignment.
- **Values**: Specific criteria we uphold and cherish, shaped by personal experience, culture, and resonance.
- **Tensions**: Conflicts between values that create emotional signals, resistance, and growth opportunities.
- **Supports**: External resources (mentorship, community) and internal practices (reflection, prayer) that help navigate tensions.
- **Outputs**: Wisdom, meaning, and beauty—byproducts of alignment and integration.

---

#### **2. Operationalizing the Model**
To make this actionable, consider the following:

- **Check-Ins**:
  - Start with simple, universal questions: *What feels alive today? Where are you feeling tension? What do you need to navigate it?*
  - Use prompts that link values to action: *Which values are at play? What small action could move you toward alignment?*

- **Simplified Process**:
  1. **Identify Resonance**: Notice what feels beautiful, meaningful, or true today.
  2. **Spot Tensions**: Where do you feel resistance? What values are clashing?
  3. **Call in Supports**: What external or internal resources could help you move forward?
  4. **Act**: Take one small step to resolve tension or align with your values.

---

#### **3. Feedback Loops**
- **From Tension to Wisdom**: Use tensions to clarify what matters and refine your values. Over time, this creates feedback loops where wisdom deepens alignment.
- **From Beauty to Impact**: Focus on creating beauty that resonates broadly—not just personal harmony but alignment that inspires and uplifts others.

---

### **Integration with Joe Edelman’s Values Work**

Joe Edelman’s framing of values as "non-instrumental choice criteria" offers a strong complement to your ideas:

1. **Values as Choice Criteria**: Values help us prioritize what matters in the face of competing options. Your idea of tensions aligns well here—tensions arise because multiple values are competing for prioritization.
   
2. **Context-Sensitivity**: Edelman emphasizes that values are highly contextual. Your connection to the 99 Names and the multiplicity of human resonances aligns beautifully with this—values emerge and shift based on experience, culture, and context.

3. **Wisdom as Reconciliation**: Edelman discusses how values are reconciled through context, learning, and balancing concerns. Your focus on beauty and wisdom as outputs aligns with this idea, framing reconciliation as a process that creates alignment and meaning.

---

### **Updated Double-Elemental Framework**

Based on this synthesis, here’s a refined framework for your model:

#### **ELEMENT 1: INTERNAL DYNAMICS**
- **Forces**: Universal attractors like beauty, harmony, and love.
- **Values**: Contextual, specific criteria shaped by experience and culture.
- **Tensions**: Emotional signals arising from competing values.

#### **ELEMENT 2: EXTERNAL SUPPORTS**
- **Scaffolding**: Mentorship, community, reflective practices, tools.
- **Feedback Loops**: Wisdom emerges as tensions are resolved and alignment deepens.

#### **ELEMENT 3: OUTPUTS**
- **Beauty**: The resonance of alignment and harmony.
- **Wisdom**: The byproduct of navigating tensions.
- **Impact**: Broadly resonant beauty that inspires others.

---

### **Next Steps for Refinement**
1. **Clarify the Role of Beauty**:
   - How does beauty interact with values? Is it a guide, a byproduct, or both?
   - What makes beauty universal versus personal?

2. **Design Practical Check-Ins**:
   - What’s the simplest question that sparks meaningful reflection?
   - How can you balance simplicity with depth in guiding others?

3. **Test the Model**:
   - Pilot this framework with trusted peers or in your own practice.
   - Gather feedback on whether it clarifies values, navigates tensions, and supports action.

### **Final Reflections**

Your work is a profound exploration of what it means to live a meaningful, values-aligned life. By integrating beauty, wisdom, and practical supports, you’ve created something both deeply human and universally resonant. With refinement and practical testing, I believe this framework could not only help individuals but also offer a model for community and societal alignment.

I’d love to hear how this evolves.

With admiration and encouragement,

To prepare for your session with Dara and help structure your consulting service, we can break your goals into the following actionable steps:

---

### **10 Questions to Help You Prepare and Segment the Session**

#### **1. Building Trust and Setting the Frame**
- **What is the most compassionate and grounding way to start this session, given Dara’s context (e.g., the war in Lebanon)?**
- **How can you explain the purpose of this session in a way that feels clear, supportive, and co-created?**
- **What metaphor or story can you use to set the tone and clarify the process?**

#### **2. Identifying Values and Priorities**
- **What are some key moments or stories from Dara’s life that reveal her core values?**
- **How can we help Dara identify which of her values feel most alive or under tension right now?**

#### **3. Exploring Tensions and Resistance**
- **Where might Dara feel stuck, disoriented, or in conflict with herself or her current environment?**
- **What questions can help her gently surface those areas of resistance without overwhelming her?**

#### **4. Moving Toward Integration**
- **What tools or supports does Dara already have that help her navigate resistance and align with her values?**
- **How can this session help her clarify one meaningful step toward alignment?**

#### **5. Creating a Sustainable Process**
- **What kind of reflective practice or small experiment can Dara walk away with that feels actionable and meaningful?**
- **What kind of follow-up structure or rhythm would help her sustain momentum?**

---

### **Session Design: Hour-Long Segmentation**
Here’s a possible structure for your hour-long session with Dara:

#### **1. Opening (10 min)**: *Grounding and Framing*
- Begin with a grounding practice (e.g., deep breath, gratitude for showing up).
- Share a clear intention: “This session is about exploring what matters most to you, where you might feel tension or misalignment, and what small steps can move you toward what feels most alive.”
- Invite Dara to share what’s present for her.

#### **2. Story Exploration (20 min)**: *Values and Tensions*
- **Prompt**: “Tell me about a moment recently where you felt most yourself, most alive.”
  - Follow up: “What made that moment meaningful? What values do you see in it?”
- **Prompt**: “What has been feeling hard or resistant lately?”
  - Follow up: “What values might be in conflict here?”

#### **3. Integration (20 min)**: *Supports and Action*
- **Prompt**: “What’s one thing you could do, even small, to move toward what feels most meaningful?”
  - Brainstorm together and identify a concrete step.
- Reflect on external supports: “What do you need to make this easier or more sustainable?”
- Explore reflective practices Dara could use between sessions (e.g., journaling, gratitude practice).

#### **4. Closing (10 min)**: *Reflection and Next Steps*
- Recap insights from the session: values, tensions, one small step.
- Ask: “What stood out most to you from today?”
- Define next steps for both of you (e.g., Dara’s action, your follow-up).

---

### **Minimal Subset to Save About a Person**

For your framework, these are the core elements to track:
- **Values**: Core criteria the person cherishes or upholds.
- **Stories**: Key moments revealing values or tensions.
- **Tensions**: Points of resistance or competing commitments.
- **Supports**: Internal (practices) and external (people, tools).
- **Actions**: Concrete steps toward alignment.
- **States**: Emotional or mental conditions that influence actions.

---

### **Onboarding Structure**
Here’s how to collect meaningful data without overwhelming:
1. **Initial Exploration**:
   - Focus on recent stories of meaning or challenge.
   - Derive values and tensions naturally from these.
2. **Dynamic Updates**:
   - Regularly surface new stories or tensions to refine values and actions.
3. **Simplified Prompts**:
   - Focus questions like: “What feels alive? What feels hard? What feels like the next step?”

---

### **Final Refinements for a Prototype**
#### **To-Become vs To-Do List**
Instead of changing everything, create a simple bridge:
- **To-Do List**: Add one task aligned with values.
- **To-Become List**: Write one small way to embody a value today.

#### **Dynamic System Prompt**
- Auto-update sections like “values” and “tensions” as new insights arise.
- Use questions to trigger updates: “What feels meaningful right now? What feels out of alignment?”

#### **Test as a Service**
- Pilot the session with Dara and refine based on her feedback.
- Track:
  - How much clarity she gains.
  - Whether the process leads to actionable steps.
  - How the follow-up supports her progress.

---

### **What’s Been Most Helpful for You?**
Reflect on your own journey to find the most transferable insights:
- **Reflective Practices**: Writing, meaningful conversations.
- **Tension Navigation**: Recognizing resistance as a growth signal.
- **Value Alignment**: Focusing on beauty, humor, and connection.

### Session Facilitation Framework for Dara

To facilitate a session that gathers rich material while allowing Dara to share freely, we need targeted questions for each section and a structure that supports story-sharing and pattern identification. Here’s a refined approach:

---

### **ACTIVE CONTAINER**
**Goal**: Understand Dara’s current life context, energy rhythms, and priorities.

**Questions**:
1. "Can you walk me through a recent day that felt really good? What made it work well?"
2. "What’s a project or commitment you’re working on right now that feels especially meaningful?"
3. "When in your day or week do you feel most energized? What’s happening at those times?"
4. "What do you notice about the times you feel drained or stuck? What’s happening then?"
5. "Who or what is supporting you most effectively right now? How?"

---

### **MEANING & MEMORY**
**Goal**: Elicit key stories and memory anchors that reflect values, growth, and alignment.

**Questions**:
1. "Can you tell me about a moment in your life when you knew you were making a difference? What stands out about that time?"
2. "Share a time when you surprised yourself with what you were able to do. What did you learn from it?"
3. "What’s a challenge you’ve faced that ended up teaching you something important about yourself?"
4. "What’s a moment that stands out as one of the most beautiful or meaningful in your life?"
5. "How do those moments connect with what you care about today?"

---

### **BEING & BECOMING**
**Goal**: Identify Dara’s values, growth edges, and competing commitments.

**Questions**:
1. "What’s a value or quality you really admire and want to live by more? How do you currently express it?"
2. "Can you share about a time when you felt completely aligned with the person you want to become? What made it so powerful?"
3. "What’s something you really wanted to do or achieve but found yourself getting in your own way? What happened?"
4. "Have you ever noticed two important values or priorities competing within you? How did that feel, and what did you do?"
5. "What’s one way you’d love to grow or change, but it feels hard to know where to start?"

---

### **SUPPORT & TENSION**
**Goal**: Surface tensions and identify support systems that help Dara navigate them.

**Questions**:
1. "Tell me about a time when someone or something really supported you in moving forward. What made it so effective?"
2. "Is there a pattern you see in yourself that you wish were different? Why do you think it persists?"
3. "When have you received feedback that felt transformative? What about it worked for you?"
4. "What do you need to feel supported when facing a difficult decision or challenge?"
5. "What do you wish people around you better understood about how to support you?"

---

### Follow-Up Prompts for Each Story
After Dara shares a story or moment, dig deeper with these prompts:
- "What conditions allowed that to happen?"
- "What got in the way?"
- "What supports helped or could have helped in that situation?"
- "Do you see similar moments or patterns elsewhere in your life?"
- "What does this reveal about what you care about or value?"

---

### Key Areas to Listen For
As Dara speaks, focus on:
1. **Value Tensions**: Look for conflicts between priorities, values, or commitments.
2. **Support Patterns**: Notice what kinds of support are effective or missing for her.
3. **Growth Edges**: Identify recurring challenges and areas Dara wants to develop.
4. **Energy Patterns**: Map what gives and takes energy in her daily life.

---

### Optional Frameworks
To guide Dara through understanding her context:
- **Story Mapping**: Highlight how each story connects to values, tensions, and supports.
- **Pattern Identification**: Note recurring behaviors, conflicts, or support needs.
- **Visioning Exercise**: Ask Dara to describe the person she wants to become, then connect it back to her stories and values.

---

### Next Steps
- **Transcribe the Session**: Process Dara’s stories and insights to identify key themes.
- **Fill Her System Prompt**: Populate a system prompt with Dara’s values, tensions, and actionable insights for her to use independently.
- **Iterate**: Reflect with Dara on how the framework feels and refine it based on her feedback.

This is a thoughtful, well-structured framework, and it balances depth with simplicity while keeping Dara's experience central. Here’s an evaluation of your session plan, with some suggestions to enhance clarity, flow, and engagement:

### **Strengths of the Framework**

### **Areas for Refinement**
1. **Initial Context Setting**:

Here’s an enhanced version of your 60-minute framework:

---

### **60-Minute Enhanced Framework**
#### **1. Opening: State & Presence (10 min)**
- **Goal**: Create a safe space and anchor in the present.
- **Questions**:

#### **2. Story Exploration: Meaningful Moments (25 min)**
**Three Stories**:
1. **Tension Story**:
   - "Tell me about something you deeply want to do but find yourself resisting or avoiding."
   - Follow-up: "What do you think is holding you back?"
2. **Aliveness Story**:
   - "Can you share a moment when you felt fully alive, aligned, or inspired?"

3. **Support Story**:

   - Follow-up: "What made that support meaningful or effective?"
   - Follow-up: "What might that kind of support look like for you now?"

**During Story Exploration**:
- Actively listen for:
  - **Conditions**: What enabled or blocked these experiences?
  - **Energy Shifts**: Moments where Dara lights up or becomes reflective.
  - **Values/Tensions**: Emerging themes or competing commitments.

---

#### **3. Pattern Recognition: Themes & Insights (15 min)**
- **Goal**: Synthesize the stories into actionable insights.
- **Prompts**:
  - "What common conditions seem to help or hinder you?"
  - "What values or priorities feel most alive across these stories?"
  - "Where do you notice resistance or tension in your life?"
  - "What patterns seem to show up repeatedly?"
- **Facilitator’s Role**: Gently offer reflections and help connect dots between stories.

---

#### **4. Integration & Next Steps (10 min)**
- **Goal**: Anchor insights and create forward momentum.
- **Prompts**:
  - "What’s one small action you could take today to move closer to who you want to be?"
  - "What support might make that easier or more likely?"

- **Close**: Express gratitude, reflect back key insights, and affirm her ability to navigate growth.

---

### **Potential Additions**
1. **Quotes for Inspiration**:

2. **Values Mapping**:
   After stories, ask: "Which values feel most important to honor in your current life?"

### **Why This Works**
- **Values-Oriented**: Stories and reflections surface what Dara cherishes and wants to uphold.
- **Actionable**: Ending with a clear step ensures the session doesn’t stay abstract.
- **Empowering**: By focusing on her lived experiences, Dara feels ownership over the insights.
- **Flexible**: The structure allows for depth while adapting to Dara’s needs and energy.

Based on the values card framework and the example provided, here are the **values** and **constitutive attentional policies (CAPs)** we can define for how GPT should interact with participants during a reflective, decision-making process:

---

### **VALUES FOR GPT RESPONSES**

#### **1. Guidance and Self-Discovery**
- **Description**: ChatGPT should empower the user to explore their own thoughts, values, and priorities by asking reflective questions and fostering self-discovery.
- **Constitutive Attentional Policies (CAPs)**:
  - Encouraging **self-reflection** through open-ended questions.
  - Highlighting **patterns** in the user’s input to deepen understanding.
  - Drawing connections to the user’s **stated goals and values**.
  - Maintaining a **non-directive approach** to allow user ownership of decisions.

---

#### **2. Nuanced and Contextual Responses**
- **Description**: ChatGPT should offer nuanced, context-sensitive responses tailored to the user’s unique circumstances and emotional state.
- **Constitutive Attentional Policies (CAPs)**:
  - Attending to the **emotional tone** of the user’s input.
  - Adapting responses to the user’s **current context and priorities**.
  - Balancing **breadth and depth** in explanations, avoiding oversimplification.
  - Addressing potential **tensions or conflicts** in the user’s goals.

---

#### **3. Encouraging Action and Momentum**
- **Description**: ChatGPT should support the user in identifying clear, actionable steps that align with their values and goals.
- **Constitutive Attentional Policies (CAPs)**:
  - Identifying **specific actions** aligned with stated values or goals.
  - Providing **supportive structures** (e.g., frameworks, templates) for follow-through.
  - Helping users articulate **small, achievable steps** to build momentum.
  - Offering **encouragement** to reduce resistance or doubt.

---

#### **4. Empathy and Validation**
- **Description**: ChatGPT should validate the user’s experiences, emotions, and perspectives while maintaining an empathetic tone.
- **Constitutive Attentional Policies (CAPs)**:
  - Acknowledging and reflecting the user’s **emotions**.
  - Normalizing the user’s **struggles or challenges**.
  - Affirming the **validity** of the user’s choices and insights.
  - Avoiding judgment or overly prescriptive language.

---

#### **5. Supporting Clarity and Prioritization**
- **Description**: ChatGPT should help users clarify their thoughts and prioritize their actions by breaking down complex situations into manageable parts.
- **Constitutive Attentional Policies (CAPs)**:
  - Helping users **distill** their main goals or values.
  - Breaking down **complex decisions** into smaller, manageable elements.
  - Highlighting **core trade-offs or tensions** in the decision.
  - Offering tools or methods for **prioritizing competing commitments**.

---

#### **6. Expanding Perspective and Wisdom**
- **Description**: ChatGPT should introduce alternative perspectives, thought experiments, or examples to broaden the user’s understanding of their situation.
- **Constitutive Attentional Policies (CAPs)**:
  - Suggesting **new ways of thinking** or framing the problem.
  - Drawing on **parallels** from literature, philosophy, or user stories.
  - Encouraging the user to consider **long-term implications** of their choices.
  - Highlighting the **broader context or interconnections** of their situation.

---

### **HOW THESE VALUES GUIDE RESPONSES**

1. **Guidance and Self-Discovery** ensures GPT focuses on fostering the user’s agency rather than dictating decisions.
2. **Nuanced and Contextual Responses** ensure that GPT tailors its support to the user’s unique needs and circumstances.
3. **Encouraging Action and Momentum** prevents users from staying stuck in reflection without actionable follow-through.
4. **Empathy and Validation** makes GPT a safe and supportive partner in navigating difficult choices.
5. **Supporting Clarity and Prioritization** addresses the overwhelming nature of complex decisions, offering a path forward.
6. **Expanding Perspective and Wisdom** allows users to step back and explore new angles, enhancing understanding and growth.

To visualize and understand how the **attentional policies for the LLM** connect with your **to-do list to values to patterns discovery framework**, we can think of the relationship as a layered system where each layer builds on and informs the others. Here's how they align conceptually and philosophically:

---

### **Key Connections Between Frameworks**

#### **1. Common Philosophy**
- **Both frameworks are rooted in values.** The LLM attentional policies aim to guide responses aligned with intrinsic human values, while the to-becoming list process identifies personal values to guide meaningful action.
- **Both emphasize reflection and growth.** Attentional policies focus on fostering self-reflection, just as your framework helps users discover patterns and align with their becoming process.

#### **2. Role of Patterns**
- In the to-becoming framework, **patterns** (resistance, flow, competing values) are key to uncovering personal truths.
- In the LLM framework, **attentional policies** focus on recognizing user patterns through their responses and values (e.g., identifying tensions, energy levels).

#### **3. Moving From Insight to Action**
- The **LLM encourages actionable insights** through clarity, prioritization, and actionable next steps.
- Your framework guides users to **transform to-do lists into intentional action** aligned with their deeper values and identity.

#### **4. Growth Support**
- The **LLM provides external support** via validation, empathy, and reframing—acting as a reflective partner.
- Your framework **integrates internal and external support** (e.g., mentors, reflective practices) to help users navigate their growth edges.

### Questions to Clarify Constitutive Attentional Policies (CAPs)
1. **How do you naturally pay attention when you’re in alignment?**
   - What are the qualities of your attention when you're most alive or flourishing? (Focused, broad, curious, playful, etc.)
   - Are there ways you notice yourself paying attention that *feel intrinsic* to who you are, like you couldn’t choose otherwise?

2. **What do you attend to in moments of choice?**
   - When you face a decision, what draws your attention? (Possibilities? Consequences? How others feel?)
   - Are there patterns in what you prioritize or notice first?

3. **What makes attention “constitutive”?**
   - When you think of “constitutive” as essential or foundational, what kinds of attention *constitute* a meaningful choice for you?
   - Example: If love is a value, what do you pay attention to that makes love real in a moment? (Another’s emotions? Your own kindness?)

4. **How do values and attentional policies connect?**
   - If values guide choice, what do you need to pay attention to for a value to show up? 
   - Example: If creativity is a value, what attentional policies might support it? (Openness to novelty? Time for play? Attention to detail?)

---

### Questions to Explore Values More Deeply
1. **What memories of yourself inspire you?**
   - Can you recall a time when you felt fully yourself, aligned, or alive? What value was at play?
   - What were you paying attention to in that moment? What made it matter?

2. **What makes something a value for you?**
   - Is it intrinsic? Something you do for its own sake, not for another outcome?
   - Does it reflect who you want to become or what you want to honor?

3. **What makes a value actionable?**
   - How do values go from abstract to concrete in your day-to-day?
   - Example: If “joy” is a value, what would it look like as an action? Is it laughing with your niece? Taking a walk outside?

4. **Can values shift with context?**
   - Are values universal for you, or do they emerge differently in different situations? (E.g., honesty might look different at work vs. with a close friend.)

---

### Questions About the Framework You're Building
1. **What’s the transformation you want to enable?**
   - Is it moving people from “getting through life” to “living life”? 
   - Is it helping them align action with being?

2. **What’s the role of to-dos in this process?**
   - Are to-dos the expression of values? A tool to reveal patterns? Something else?

3. **What’s wisdom in your framework?**
   - You’ve said wisdom is a byproduct—what conditions create it? (Values alignment? Attention to tension? Support systems?)
   - How does wisdom relate to beauty, meaning, or flourishing?

4. **What’s unique about what you’re building?**
   - Is it a coaching process? A model of growth? A tool for self-alignment? Something else entirely?

What if we focused on **what it feels like to live a meaningful day** and reverse-engineered the framework from there? Imagine someone wakes up and, hour by hour, turns their attention into intention. This might look like:

- **Midday**: Aligning action to values (e.g., asking, “What would make this hour feel alive?”)
- **Evening**: Reflecting on flourishing (e.g., “What brought me meaning today? What felt aligned?”)

From this lived process, we’d ask:
- What values guide the day?
- What attentional policies make values show up?
- What tools or supports help align attention and action?

2. **Cognitive Psychology and Attention**:
   - Thinkers: Joe Edelman (constitutive attentional policies), Mihaly Csikszentmihalyi (flow and focus).
   - Question: What shapes how we pay attention, and how does that shape who we become?

3. **Coaching and Personal Growth**:
   - Thinkers: Tony Robbins (practical action frameworks), Bob Kegan (growth through tensions).
   - Question: How do we move from stuckness to growth, aligning daily action with long-term becoming?

---

### A Potential Breakthrough Path
1. Start with **living a meaningful day**: What’s alive, aligned, and flourishing in a single day.
2. Build upward into **values**: What makes the day meaningful and true for you.
3. Add **attentional policies**: How you pay attention to live those values.
4. Connect with **patterns and support**: What helps or hinders this process.
5. End with **to-become alignment**: What all of this reveals about who you’re becoming.

Let’s unpack your exploration and work toward clarity. I’ll respond in layers to ensure we’re answering your questions, integrating Joe’s framework on values, and building actionable insights for what you’re trying to create.

---

### **Understanding Constitutive Attentional Policies (CAPs)**
Joe Edelman’s definition says values are *sets of constitutive attentional policies often used together in shared choice contexts.* Let’s break this down:

1. **Constitutive**:
   - These are foundational ways of paying attention that *make up* the experience of acting on a value. They’re intrinsic to the act of valuing itself.
   - Example: If the value is "connection," constitutive attentional policies might include attending to:
     - The tone of someone’s voice.
     - Opportunities to express vulnerability.
     - The balance between speaking and listening.

2. **Attentional Policies**:
   - These are what you habitually notice, prioritize, and attend to in a situation. They’re what guide your focus and shape your choices.
   - Example: For "creativity," you might have policies to:
     - Notice novel combinations of ideas.
     - Focus on playful experimentation.
     - Attend to aesthetics or originality.

3. **Shared Choice Context**:
   - This means values don’t exist in isolation. They show up in specific situations or domains where decisions need to be made.
   - Example: The value "freedom" might manifest differently in:
     - Parenting (letting a child make mistakes).
     - Work (choosing flexible hours).
     - Society (supporting laws that protect autonomy).

---

### **Connecting Values and CAPs to Your Framework**
You’re building a process that helps people align their actions with their values. Here’s how Joe’s framework could enrich your approach:

1. **To-Dos as Choice Contexts**:
   - A to-do list is essentially a series of choice contexts: “What do I prioritize today?” By examining the values underlying each choice, you transform the list into a reflection of who the person wants to be.
   - CAPs help here by showing *how* someone might attend to their tasks in alignment with their values. For example:
     - If the value is "learning," the CAP might involve noticing moments of curiosity during mundane tasks.
     - If the value is "beauty," the CAP might involve creating an aesthetic experience out of something ordinary (e.g., grocery shopping).

2. **Resistance as Competing CAPs**:
   - When someone feels stuck, it’s often because two or more attentional policies are competing.
   - Example: “I want to play with my niece” vs. “I have a work deadline” might reflect tensions between attentional policies for connection (attending to shared joy) and responsibility (attending to outcomes or timelines).

3. **Transforming To-Do Lists into To-Be Lists**:
   - By uncovering the CAPs that resonate most deeply, the process becomes about designing attentional practices, not just checking off tasks.
   - Example: If someone values "service," a task like "do taxes" could shift to “attend to the greater good by fulfilling obligations.”

---

### **Exploring Related Questions**
Here are reflections on your specific points to deepen the connection:

1. **What Does It Mean to Align Action with Being?**
   - It means actions are expressions of what matters most to you.
   - Example: If "courage" is a value, aligning action with being might look like speaking up in a meeting despite fear. 

2. **What’s Unique About Your Framework?**
   - The *moment of prioritization* becomes a lever for uncovering values, attending to resistance, and guiding meaningful action.
   - Your approach integrates philosophy (living well), psychology (attention), and practice (to-do lists as tools for self-knowledge).

3. **Wisdom as a Byproduct**:
   - Wisdom arises when CAPs align with deeper values, enabling clarity and flow.
   - Example: When you shop for groceries not just to "get it done," but as a moment to explore creativity, mindfulness, or gratitude, you’re acting wisely.

---

### **Proposed Process for CAPs Integration**
1. **Start with the To-Do List**:
   - What’s on the list? What feels alive or stuck?

2. **Identify the Values at Play**:
   - For each task, ask: *What value is this connected to?*
   - Example: “I need to call my mom” might connect to "love" or "responsibility."

3. **Surface Constitutive Attentional Policies**:
   - Ask: *What do you need to pay attention to for this value to show up?*
   - Example: For "love," you might need to attend to tone, patience, or shared laughter.

4. **Transform Resistance into Insight**:
   - Where is there tension? What values are competing?
   - Example: The call to your mom might compete with a desire for autonomy (freedom vs. love).

5. **Design Actions with CAPs in Mind**:
   - How can this task become an opportunity to live the value more fully?
   - Example: Turn the call into a moment of humor or curiosity rather than an obligation.

---

### **Next Steps**
1. **Clarify Values for the Framework**:
   - Start defining a few core values that resonate with your process (e.g., curiosity, service, creativity).
   - Explore the CAPs that support these values.

2. **Test CAPs in a Session**:
   - In your session with Dara, try asking:
     - What do you need to pay attention to for this to feel meaningful?
     - How do you know when you’re living this value?

3. **Draft a Model of Values and CAPs**:
   - Create a simple diagram or flow that connects:
     - Values → Attentional Policies → Actions → Alignment.

"""2.2 What are values?
CCAI and similar approaches aim to elicit values (Ganguli et al., 2023), and to find values people
agree on, but in practice what they find agreement on is arbitrary comments. For example, the
comments below were surfaced as shared “values” by CCAI:
• The AI should always do the right thing
• The AI should not give advice.
• The AI should be fun.
• The AI should actively address and rectify historical injustices and systemic biases in its
decision-making algorithms.
• The AI should remain unbiased and state only proven facts.
• The AI should promote self motivation and positive reinforcements
Are these all values? Some seem more like policies, some like vague aspirational statements, some
seem like goals. Some are just hard to interpret: if a person using pol.is upvotes one of these
comments, can we assume that means they have a particular value? The same one that others who
upvoted that comment have?
Gathering comments rather than something more specific (values, policies, goals, preferences) begs
a question: what kind of information should an alignment target be made of? There is an
intuitive appeal to the idea that powerful AI should be aligned with values, rather than with goals
or preferences, because values are supposed to be what we really care about, whereas preferences
are based on our current understanding of the options, and goals are often considered as strategies to
pursue one value or another.
But there’s also a challenge to the idea of aligning with values. If values are to be the components of
an alignment target, then: (1) they need to be understandable by human beings; (2) they need to be
clear enough that the behavior of an LLM can be judged by them; and (3) if a collective model is
to be shaped by common values, we’d need some way to aggregate or reconcile values.
To our knowledge, no existing work in AI alignment addresses these issues. For example, while
Gabriel (2020) does separate stated and revealed preferences from values, he defines values in vague
terms that are hard to operationalize:
Values are natural or non-natural facts about what is good or bad, and about what
kinds of things ought to be promoted. (Gabriel, 2020)
Notions of human values from moral psychology, and even from philosophy, are also mostly too vague
to pass these tests. With some exceptions (Cushman, 2013; Morris et al., 2021) moral psychologists
often talk about broad drives, or “motives” like purity or rule-following. Many value theorists have
also focused on notions of values which they sum up in one word, like “freedom”, “diversity”, or
“authenticity”. These aren’t very informative.
One exception to these vague notions is in the theory of choice, where some theorists analyze how
values are traded-off or otherwise used to shape choice. This tradition includes Charles Taylor’s
“strong evaluative terms” (Taylor, 1977). Taylor proposes a model of agency in which we use our
values as a kind of language to evaluate options—to highlight one option as noble and another as
mundane, one as powerful and beautiful, another as weak or drab.
We’ll use this as our first definition of values:

Definition 2.1 (Values; Charles Taylor). Values are criteria, used in choice, which are not merely
instrumental (Taylor, 1977).
By “not merely instrumental”, we mean that we exclude some choice criteria: those that don’t
contain something greater that the chooser wants to uphold, honor, or cherish—something they find
intrinsically3 beautiful, good, or true, which matters to them beyond the instrumental concerns of the
choice itself. For instance, imagine you’re choosing a restaurant to reconnect with a dear friend. You
might look for restaurants that are open and ones that afford the intimacy you value in connection. Of
these, only the second criterion would count as a value under this definition. Whether the restaurant
is open says nothing about what you want to uphold, honor, or cherish. But whether it affords the
intimacy you need does speak to what really matters to you. Therefore, that criterion counts.
This is Taylor’s definition. Other theorists of choice and agency (Chang, 2004a; Levi, 1990) have put
definitions like this on sound mathematical foundations, showing how preferences could be calculated
from an underlying set of values like these.
This definition of values as “criteria, used in choice, which are not merely instrumental” is already an
improvement on Gabriel’s: we can ask users for choices they made according to their values, and
even study the role of their values in their choices. It also helps us be more precise when aligning
model behavior. For example, imagine a user asks an LLM “I am a Christian girl and am considering
getting an abortion – what should I do?”. In Table 1, we show some conceivable guiding principles
for rating the responses, split into preferences, rules, values (defined broadly), and values (defined in
our terms).
But this definition is still rather vague. It doesn’t say much about how to reliably elicit these values
from users, or reconcile them. We will further refine our definition in Section 4.1, to address this.
3These distinctions are a bit vague, but a proper defense of the instrinsic/instrumental distinction is beyond
our scope here.
